person_266.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
person_266.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

person_866.name: Benoitde Maillet
person_866.description: French natural philosopher who presented controversial evolutionary speculations.

person_906.name: Leucippus
person_906.description: a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher. He is traditionally credited as the founder of atomism, which he developed with his student Democritus. Leucippus divided the world into two entities: atoms, indivisible particles that make up all things, and the void, the nothingness that exists between the atoms.

person_505.name: EdmondHalley
person_505.description: Astronomer and natural philosopher, who, using Newtonian mechanics, predicted the return of what became the eponymous comet. FRSL.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_039.name: JohnWoodward
person_039.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_033.name: Torbern OlafBergman
person_033.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

person_1000.name: JohnWhitehurst
person_1000.description: a clockmaker and scientist who made significant early contributions to geology and was an influential member of the Lunar Society.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_520.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
person_520.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

person_247.name: CarlLinnaeus
person_247.description: Professor of Physic and Botany at Uppsala University. Developed the modern system of taxonomic classification. ForMemFRSL.

person_151.name: Edward CharlesHoward
person_151.description: A brother of the Duke of Norfolk, he became a chemist, discovering the explosive properties of mercury fulminate. FRSL

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_267.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
person_267.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

person_263.name: Pluto
person_263.description: The ruler of the underworld in ancient Greek mythology and religion.

person_164.name: JamesHall
person_164.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

person_1064.name: Clement
person_1064.description: Clement of Alexandria was a Christian theologian and philosopher

person_162.name: JohnPlayfair
person_162.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

place_1094.name: Cairo
place_1094.description: Cairo is the capital of Egypt

place_1191.name: Mediterranean Sea
place_1191.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

place_492.name: Derby
place_492.description: Derby is an English city on the banks of the River Derwent in Derbyshire.

place_085.name: Derbyshire
place_085.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

place_169.name: Mount Vesuvius
place_169.description: Mount Vesuvius is a somma-stratovolcano located on the Gulf of Naples in Campania, Italy.

place_184.name: Mount Etna
place_184.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

place_247.name: Alps
place_247.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_226.name: Geneva
place_226.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

place_991.name: Freiberg
place_991.description: A university and former mining town in Saxony, Germany
